# Taking a Physical Approach to Complexity

$\mathbf{A} = \mathbf{U}\cdot\mathbf{\Sigma}\cdot\mathbf{V}^T$

$m \times m$ orthogonal matrix and
$\mathbf{V}$ an $n \times n$ orthogonal matrix. The columns in these matrices
are, respectively, the left- and right-singular vectors of $\mathbf{A}$.
$\mathbf{\Sigma}$ is a diagonal matrix, where $\sigma_{i} = \Sigma_{ii}$, which contains the singular values of $\mathbf{A}$. When the values of
$\mathbf{\sigma}$ are arranged in descending order, the singular values are
